bioghist.p: John McDowell (1870-1937) was Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. He served as Secretary of the Board of National Missions and Secretary of the Committee on Social and Industrial Relations of the Board of National Missions. He was noted for his Labor Day sermons. Scottish-born, a onetime breaker boy in a Pennsylvania mine (where he lost an arm), McDowell worked his way through Mount Hermon School at East Northfield. Massachusetts, and became a friend of Founder Dwight Lyman Moody.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of John McDowell, including typescripts and printed copies of sermons and addresses; news releases of statements; printed messages of the Board of National Missions and the General Assembly, including a "Labor Day Message"; a small amount of correspondence with the Publicity Department of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.; and a broadside of a report of the Standing Committee on Social Welfare, 1937. Topics of the addresses in the collection include labor and the church, the economic crisis, the church and social and industrial relations, and unemployment.
